required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prediction of Delivery With Transperineal Ultrasound in Women With Prolonged Labour. Multicentre Study
clinical_study.official_title: Prediction of Mode of Delivery With Transperineal Ultrasound in Women With Prolonged First Stage of Labour. A Multicentre Study

collaborator.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology
Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock:
Objectives
1. To assess if head-perineum distance and angle of progression measured with transperineal ultrasound by the obstetrician on call can predict delivery mode in primiparous women with prolonged first stage of labour.
2. To compare ultrasound assessments and clinical examinations.

detailed_description.textblock:
Variables Digitally assessed cervical dilatation, fetal station and position Ultrasound measured fetal head-perineum distance. Ultrasound measured angle of progression Ultrasound assessed position
Possible confounders Ethnicity, maternal age, gestational age, BMI, induction of labour, augmentation, epidural analgesia, birth weight, head circumference
A two-dimensional ultrasound measurement will be obtained with the ultrasound device available in the delivery department. Fetal head descent is measured as the shortest distance between the outer bony limit of the fetal skull and the perineum with a curved transabdominal transducer placed transperineally between the labia in a transverse view (1).
The fetal descent will also be assessed measuring "angle of progression" as suggested by Barbera et al. The ultrasound transducer will be placed on the perineum in a mid-sagittal position between the labia below the pubic symphysis. The angle between a line through the symphysis and a line from the posterior part of the symphysis tangentially to the fetal skull contour will be measured (2)
A transabdominal scan will also be performed determining the fetal position as described previously. Positions ≥ 02.30 and ≤ 03.30 hours should be recorded as left occiput transverse and positions ≥ 08.30 and ≤ 09.30 as right occiput transverse. Positions > 03.30 and <08.30 should be recorded as occiput posterior and positions > 09.30 and < 02.30 as occiput anterior.(3).

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Women With Vaginal Deliveries
primary_outcome.description: Women were categorized in accordance to fetal descent measured by ultrasound. Head-perineum distance (HPD) ≤40 mm and angle of progression (AoP) ≥110 degrees were used as cut-off level. HPD was obtained in all 150 cases and AoP was successfully obtained in 145 cases.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Women With Cesarean Section
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of women with cesarean section was compared in cases with occiput posterior position and cases with non occiput posterior position assessed with transabdominal sonography when prolonged labor was diagnosed.

arm_group.description: primiparous women with prolonged labours will be eligible for examination

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Primiparous women with single pregnancies and gestation age > 37 weeks and prolonged first stage of labor
Exclusion Criteria:
- High risk pregnancies,
- premature deliveries,
- multiple pregnancies

reference.citation: Torkildsen EA, Salvesen KÅ, Eggebø TM. Prediction of delivery mode with transperineal ultrasound in women with prolonged first stage of labor. Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol. 2011 Jun;37(6):702-8. doi: 10.1002/uog.8951. Epub 2011 May 3.

Barbera AF, Pombar X, Perugino G, Lezotte DC, Hobbins JC. A new method to assess fetal head descent in labor with transperineal ultrasound. Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol. 2009 Mar;33(3):313-9. doi: 10.1002/uog.6329.
Akmal S, Tsoi E, Kametas N, Howard R, Nicolaides KH. Intrapartum sonography to determine fetal head position. J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med. 2002 Sep;12(3):172-7.

results_reference.citation: Eggebø TM, Hassan WA, Salvesen KÅ, Lindtjørn E, Lees CC. Sonographic prediction of vaginal delivery in prolonged labor: a two-center study. Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol. 2014 Feb;43(2):195-201. doi: 10.1002/uog.13210. Epub 2013 Dec 22.

Eggebø TM, Hassan WA, Salvesen KÅ, Torkildsen EA, Østborg TB, Lees CC. Prediction of delivery mode by ultrasound-assessed fetal position in nulliparous women with prolonged first stage of labor. Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol. 2015 Nov;46(5):606-10. doi: 10.1002/uog.14773. Epub 2015 Sep 28.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment was from 1. January 2012 until 30. April 2013

group.title: Results From Transperineal Scan
group.description: Primiparous women with prolonged labours was eligible for the study. Addenbrooke’s Hospital, Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Cambridge, UK and Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Stavanger University Hospital, Stavanger, Norway participated. Ultrasound examination: a transperineal sonography was done when prolonged labor was diagnosed. Prolonged labor was diagnosed in accordance with WHO recommendations in Stavanger and in accordance with NICE guidelines in Cambridge

group.title: Transperineal Ultrasound
group.description: Fetal head descent was assessed using a transperineal scan

outcome.title: Percentage of Women With Vaginal Deliveries
outcome.description: Women were categorized in accordance to fetal descent measured by ultrasound. Head-perineum distance (HPD) ≤40 mm and angle of progression (AoP) ≥110 degrees were used as cut-off level. HPD was obtained in all 150 cases and AoP was successfully obtained in 145 cases.
outcome.population: AoP could not be measured in 5 cases because only a part of the symphysis was visualized.

group.title: Transperineal Ultrasound
group.description: Fetal head descent was assessed using a transperineal scan

measure.title: Percentage of Women With Vaginal Deliveries
measure.description: Women were categorized in accordance to fetal descent measured by ultrasound. Head-perineum distance (HPD) ≤40 mm and angle of progression (AoP) ≥110 degrees were used as cut-off level. HPD was obtained in all 150 cases and AoP was successfully obtained in 145 cases.
measure.population: AoP could not be measured in 5 cases because only a part of the symphysis was visualized.
measure.units: percentage of participants in each group

class.title: Vaginal deliveries if HPD was ≤40 mm (n=84)
Vaginal deliveries if HPD was >40 mm (n=66)
Vaginal deliveries if AoP was ≥110 degrees (n=84)
Vaginal deliveries if AoP was <110 degrees (n=61)

analysis.groups_desc: Women were categorized in accordance to fetal descent measured by ultrasound. Head-perineum distance ≤40 mm was used as cut-off level. Vaginal delivery was the primary outcome measure.
analysis.p_value_desc: A sample size calculation with alpha 0.05, power 0.8, and cut-off level of HPD at 40 mm. 146 women should be included. The calculation was based from a previous study, in which 93% with HPD ≤40 mm and 57% of with HPD > 40 mm delivered vaginally.

outcome.title: Percentage of Women With Cesarean Section
outcome.description: The percentage of women with cesarean section was compared in cases with occiput posterior position and cases with non occiput posterior position assessed with transabdominal sonography when prolonged labor was diagnosed.
outcome.population: Fetal head position was assessed successfully using transabdominal ultrasound in 142/150 women. Position could not be diagnosed in eight cases due to shadowing from maternal pelvis in cases at low stations.

group.title: Transabdominal Ultrasound
group.description: Fetal head position was assessed using a transabdominal scan

measure.title: Percentage of Women With Cesarean Section
measure.description: The percentage of women with cesarean section was compared in cases with occiput posterior position and cases with non occiput posterior position assessed with transabdominal sonography when prolonged labor was diagnosed.
measure.population: Fetal head position was assessed successfully using transabdominal ultrasound in 142/150 women. Position could not be diagnosed in eight cases due to shadowing from maternal pelvis in cases at low stations.
measure.units: percentage of participants in each group

class.title: Cesarean section in cases with OP position (n=50)
Cesarean sin cases with non-OP position (n=92)

group.title: Transabdominal and Transperineal Sonography
group.description: Fetal head position was assessed using a transabdominal scan and fetal station was assessed by transperineal scan

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
